docs.abstract: The Apple Watch is hardly a failure, but its sluggish takeoff reveals the cracks in the company’s mythology.
docs.snippet: The Apple Watch is hardly a failure, but its sluggish takeoff reveals the cracks in the company’s mythology.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple opened a routine product-launch event last month with a gag. An establishing aerial shot of Apple’s new circular headquarters set up a “Mission: Impossible”-inspired video sketch: The keynote speech is about to start, and it’s an emergency. A young woman is summoned into action, clutching a metallic briefcase while running, jumping, tripping and sliding her way out of the sparsely inhabited mile-round structure where she works. This rush across Apple’s depopulated futurescape is interrupted by an Apple Watch notifying our hero that she had completed her activity goal for the day; she runs into a colleague who uses his to teleport. The real punch line arrives when she delivers her package to Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook — and it’s not a new product, but the remote control he needs for his presentation.

headline.main: Apple Used to Know Exactly What People Wanted — Then It Made a Watch

docs.abstract: Apple is part of a group of giant companies that dominate the United States economy. That is good for financial markets, but not necessarily for everyone else.
docs.snippet: Apple is part of a group of giant companies that dominate the United States economy. That is good for financial markets, but not necessarily for everyone else.
docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel. General Motors. AT&T. Exxon Mobil.

headline.main: Apple’s $1 Trillion Milestone Reflects Rise of Powerful Megacompanies
headline.print_headline: Apple Hits $1 Trillion Threshold. At What Cost?

docs.abstract: Large technology companies, and the big profits they produce, lifted the markets earlier this year. But during October’s tumble they were only part of a broad-based downturn.
docs.snippet: Large technology companies, and the big profits they produce, lifted the markets earlier this year. But during October’s tumble they were only part of a broad-based downturn.
docs.lead_paragraph: The world’s largest technology companies drove the stock market to record highs earlier this year. As stocks have tumbled, though, it’s more like they’re just along for the ride.

headline.main: Tech Drove Stocks Skyward. It Was a Different Story on the Way Down.
headline.print_headline: Market Soared On Tech’s Back, Then It Soured All on Its Own

docs.abstract: Investors’ unease over the technology sector’s prospects appeared to be fueling the broad market sell-off.
docs.snippet: Investors’ unease over the technology sector’s prospects appeared to be fueling the broad market sell-off.
docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks dropped on Monday, giving back a slice of their recent gains as investors dumped shares in some of the large technology companies that hold outsize sway over major market indexes.

headline.main: Stocks Dive After Apple Supplier Slashes Outlook
headline.print_headline: Stocks & Bonds; Apple Stumbles, Dragging Tech Giants Into a Slump

byline.original: By Stephen Grocer and Matt Phillips

docs.abstract: Just a few years ago, Microsoft was seen as a lumbering has-been. Now it’s a contender for the title of the world’s most valuable company.
docs.snippet: Just a few years ago, Microsoft was seen as a lumbering has-been. Now it’s a contender for the title of the world’s most valuable company.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, Microsoft was seen as a lumbering has-been of the technology world.

headline.main: Microsoft Is Worth as Much as Apple. How Did That Happen?
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Is Worth as Much as Apple. How Did That Happen?

docs.abstract: Days after Google, Facebook and Apple removed Infowars content, the app from the right-wing conspiracy site has surged in downloads.
docs.snippet: Days after Google, Facebook and Apple removed Infowars content, the app from the right-wing conspiracy site has surged in downloads.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just days after Google, Facebook and Apple purged videos and podcasts from the right-wing conspiracy site Infowars from their sites, the Infowars app has become one of the hottest in the country.

headline.main: Tech Companies Banned Infowars. Now, Its App Is Trending.
headline.print_headline: Infowars App Is Trending As Platforms Ban Content

docs.abstract: The elimination leaves Mr. Jones with a dearth of avenues to reach a mainstream audience.
docs.snippet: The elimination leaves Mr. Jones with a dearth of avenues to reach a mainstream audience.
docs.lead_paragraph: The bad news for Alex Jones, the notorious internet conspiracy theorist, keeps coming.

headline.main: Alex Jones’s Infowars Is Removed From Apple’s App Store

docs.abstract: The iPhone maker is the most valuable company in the world. But many believe its artificial intelligence technology falls short of its rivals.
docs.snippet: The iPhone maker is the most valuable company in the world. But many believe its artificial intelligence technology falls short of its rivals.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple has hired Google’s chief of search and artificial intelligence, John Giannandrea, a major coup in its bid to catch up to the artificial intelligence technology of its rivals.

headline.print_headline: Lagging Rivals in A.I., Apple Adds A Top Google Executive to Its Team

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Cade Metz

docs.abstract: Caught in the trade fight between Washington and Beijing, Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has become something of an envoy while trying to protect the company’s business in China.
docs.snippet: Caught in the trade fight between Washington and Beijing, Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has become something of an envoy while trying to protect the company’s business in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, may be the leader of the world’s most valuable public company, but lately he has had to act a lot like the tech industry’s top diplomat.

headline.main: In China Trade War, Apple Worries It Will Be Collateral Damage

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Paul Mozur

docs.abstract: Apple is using its five-day software conference to address two themes hovering over the tech industry: an erosion of privacy and smartphone addiction.
